docs.title: Welcome to the ApneaScrap Lab Blog
docs.text:
We're starting a blog to share progress on DIY freediving gear and testing. Stay tuned for updates.

This space will host:

  • Research notes that capture experiments and the theory behind our DIY projects.
  • Updates on builds, repairs, and anything else happening in the lab.
  • Brainstorming sessions where we think through solutions to tricky problems.
  • Field tests as we take prototypes into the water and report what worked (and what didn't).

docs.title: Research Notes: Foot Pockets for a Short Carbon Training Fin
docs.text:
I want to build a short carbon bifin for pool and training. Before cutting any carbon, I need to choose the foot pocket. These notes collect what I’ve learned so far.

The main questions:

  1. Which pockets are most commonly used, and why?
  2. Which ones fit DIY blades without heavy mods?
  3. How much do blade angle and rails matter for short fins?
  4. Where can I find solid references?

docs.title: 1. Popular models
docs.text:
• C4 – lightweight, multiple stiffness options
  • Pathos – 33° angle, minimal rubber for direct power transfer
  • CETMA S-WiNG – ultralight, no side rails
  • Leaderfins Classic – integrated rails
  • SEAC – comfort-oriented
  • Mares Razor / Omer Stingray – widely available, classic rubber pockets

docs.title: 2. DIY blade compatibility
docs.text:
These freediving foot pockets are known to accept third-party or home-made blades:

  • Cetma Composites S-WiNG
  • Mares Razor
  • Pathos
  • Capt. Nemo
  • Sporasub
  • OMER Stingray
  • UltraFins

docs.title: 3. Angle considerations
docs.text:
• Blade angle usually between 20°–33°.
  • Larger angles favor surface swimming and gliding, but reduce blade snap.
  • Smaller angles (or flat pockets) suit continuous kicking, often better for short fins.

docs.title: 4. Rail considerations
docs.text:
• Rails stiffen the blade and channel water.
  • Long, thick rails can dampen flex and reduce reactivity — especially noticeable on shorter blades.
  • Finding: small rails at the foot pocket let the carbon blade flex and generate thrust more effectively.

docs.title: 5. References
docs.text:
• C4 guide to pockets and blades (PDF)
  • Leaderfins foot pockets
  • UltraFins foot pockets

docs.title: Research Notes: Monofin Foot Pockets
docs.text:
This is the second half of my research — this time looking at monofin foot pockets. Most DIY monofins seem to either use dedicated monofin pockets or just adapt bifin pockets. I want to collect the options here to see which direction makes sense for a DIY build.

The main problems I need to solve are: 1. What dedicated monofin pockets exist 2. How bifin pockets get adapted for monofins 3. Which options make sense for training vs. performance

docs.title: Dedicated Monofin Foot Pockets
docs.text:
A couple of manufacturers make pockets specifically for monofins:

  • Waterway Monofin Pockets Flat (not angled) design. Old-school style, simple and sturdy.

  • CETMA Modular Monofin Uses a modular system so blades can be swapped. Also not angled.

Both are purpose-built for monofins, but the lack of angle might make them feel stiffer and less ergonomic compared to Pathos-style bifin pockets.

docs.title: Adapted Bifin Pockets for Monofins
docs.text:
It turns out a lot of commercial monofins just adapt bifin foot pockets:

  • Waterway Nemo Wing Monofin – looks like standard bifin pockets mounted onto a monofin blade.
  • Oceaner Carbon Monofin – same idea, bifin-style pockets glued/attached to a wide blade.

This approach is appealing for DIY because bifin pockets are easier to source, and I can choose comfort/angle (Pathos, SEAC, Leaderfins, etc.) based on preference.

docs.title: Training Monofins
docs.text:
For pool work and technique training, there are monofins built specifically for fast tempo kicking:

  • Finis Evo Monofin – small blade, very quick response, designed for swimming drills.

Not a traditional freediving monofin, but worth noting as inspiration for a short, snappy training blade.

docs.title: References I Don’t Want to Lose
docs.text:
• Waterway monofin pockets
  • CETMA modular monofin system
  • Waterway Nemo Wing monofin
  • Oceaner Carbon Monofin
  • Finis Evo training monofin

docs.title: Where I’m At
docs.text:
Right now I see two directions:

  • Dedicated monofin pockets (Waterway, CETMA) → simple but not angled, less ergonomic.
  • Bifin pockets adapted to monofins (Waterway Nemo Wing, Oceaner) → more flexibility, and I can pick pockets I already like (Pathos, SEAC, Leaderfins).

For DIY, the adapted bifin pocket route looks way easier and gives me more control over comfort and angle. That might be the smarter first step before I experiment with dedicated monofin pockets.

docs.title: Research Notes: DIY Carbon Bifin BOM
docs.text:
Now that I’ve mapped out the foot pockets, I want to gather everything I need for actually building a short carbon bifin blade. This is basically my BOM (bill of materials) plus a few notes on layering and finishing.

The problems I need to solve here are: 1. Which carbon fabrics and resin to use 2. How to prepare and laminate properly 3. What to use as a support base 4. How many layers are typical for bifins 5. How to finish the blades with rails and glue

docs.title: Core Materials
docs.text:
Carbon cloths (from Easy Composites): - 210 g 3k plain weave - 200 g 3k plain weave (same as above) - 200 g 3k green twill — decorative option - 650 g 12k twill — heavy, budget-friendly stiffness - 450 g 12k twill - 300 g 3k biaxial ±45° — for torsional strength

Carbon ribbons: - 80 g spread-tow ribbon, 15 mm — useful for reinforcement strips along rails or centerline.

Epoxy resin: - EL2 Epoxy Laminating Resin

docs.title: Prep and Vacuum
docs.text:
• Easylease chemical release agent or Mould Release Wax
  • Peel Ply
  • Breather Fabric
  • Vacuum Bagging Film — useful video: VB160 tutorial

docs.title: Support Base
docs.text:
I’ll need a flat sheet to laminate against:

  • Polycarbonate glazing sheet
  • Wickes Durable Clear Acrylic Sheet
  • Toolstation polycarbonate sheet

I still need to test which one works best. Acrylic scratches, polycarbonate might flex, but both should be fine for smaller training fins.

docs.title: Layering and Sizes
docs.text:
From the references I found:

  • Leaderfins → 7–8 layers, blade size ~24 cm × 54 cm
  • C4 → 7 layers, but much longer (around 90 cm)
  • DIY YouTube builds → around 6 layers

For a short training bifin, I’m probably aiming at 6–7 layers, depending on stiffness.

Reference image: Leaderfins carbon stereofins

docs.title: Finishing
docs.text:
Rails: - Waterway fin rails kit - Rail glues mentioned: Loctite 480 or 3M Marine 5200 - Good reading on rails: Spearfishing World thread

The rails help channel water and also protect the blade edge.

docs.title: References I Don’t Want to Lose
docs.text:
• Easy Composites Laminating Starter Kit
  • Easy Composites vacuum bagging film tutorial
  • Leaderfins carbon stereofins photo

docs.title: Where I’m At
docs.text:
For a short carbon training bifin, I’ll probably go with: - ~6–7 layers of 200 g 3k fabric, maybe mixing in a heavier layer (450–650 g) for stiffness - EL2 epoxy resin - Laminating on an acrylic/polycarbonate sheet - Adding rails with Loctite 480 after trimming

This should give me a small, stiff blade that can take some abuse during training without overcomplicating the build.

docs.title: Research Notes: DIY Carbon Monofin BOM
docs.text:
After mapping out bifins, I want to gather materials and design notes for building a monofin blade. This will be a bit more complex than bifins because monofins need more lateral stability and usually use internal reinforcements.

The problems I need to solve are: 1. Which materials carry over from the bifin build 2. What extra elements a monofin blade needs (ribs, edge trims, reinforcements) 3. Typical dimensions of monofins 4. How many layers are used in commercial examples 5. How to finish the blade for durability

docs.title: Core Materials
docs.text:
Most of the BOM is the same as the bifins:

  • Carbon cloths (200–650 g, plain weave, twill, biaxial)
  • Carbon ribbons (spread-tow strips for reinforcement)
  • EL2 epoxy laminating resin
  • Release agent / mould wax
  • Peel ply + breather + vacuum bagging film

docs.title: Monofin-Specific Materials
docs.text:
• Rubber U-channel trim — protects blade edges from chipping
  • Neoprene strips / rubber — add lateral stiffness and stabilize the blade
  • High-density neoprene sheet — used in some designs for damping and structural support

These help with lateral stability, which is critical in a wide monofin blade.

docs.title: Sizes and Dimensions
docs.text:
Some references from commercial monofins:

  • Molchanovs PRO Monofin 4 (Regular): 72–74 cm length × 70 cm width
  • Molchanovs PRO Monofin 4 (Small): 70–72 cm length × 68 cm width
  • Cetma Taras Monofin: max width ~69 cm

So the range seems to be 70–74 cm wide, 68–74 cm long.

Reference article: Apneapassion on Cetma Taras dimensions

docs.title: Layering
docs.text:
From examples I’ve seen:

  • 10+ layers is common for full carbon monofins
  • Many use internal carbon ribs for stiffness distribution

Visual references: - Oceaner monofin layering - Cetma Taras internal structure - Bluewater Freediving ribs example

docs.title: Internal and Side Reinforcements
docs.text:
Most high-end monofins use reinforcement structures:

  • Internal ribs: strips of carbon inside the laminate for stiffness
  • Strong side ribs: thicker rails or carbon laminates that act like wings, resisting side flex
  • Examples:
  • Waterway 6-rib system
  • Molchanovs monofin
  • Goldfin side ribs
  • Junko Kitahama competition fin

docs.title: Finishing
docs.text:
• Edge protection: rubber U-channel trim
  • Rails (optional, depending on how stable the blade feels)
  • Sanded and rounded blade edges for safety and durability

docs.title: References I Don’t Want to Lose
docs.text:
• DIY monofin forum thread
  • Cetma Taras monofin breakdown
  • Oceaner carbon monofin layering
  • Bluewater Freediving internal ribs example

docs.title: Where I’m At
docs.text:
Compared to bifins, a DIY monofin clearly needs: - More layers (10+) for stiffness - Internal ribs to control flex and power transfer - Side reinforcements to prevent wobbling - Rubber edge trim for protection

The challenge will be building internal ribs into the laminate. That’s probably the biggest difference compared to the simpler bifin build.

docs.title: Research Notes: Blade Stiffness and Profiles
docs.text:
I finally pulled together a quick reference for how tip load ("hardness") and bending profile play together on long freediving blades. The clearest explanation I have found so far comes from this breakdown: ▶️ Blade stiffness explained.

The short version: two variables define how a blade feels in the water.

  • Load (tip stiffness in kg) — how much weight it takes to bend the blade to 90°.
  • Bending profile — where the blade gives way once it reaches that load.

The Fin Flex Comparison Chart and its stiffness plot show fin stiffness spanning roughly 15–40 units of force across the models compared.

Ninety degrees is the useful limit. After that the blade just folds over, stalls, and stops storing energy. Most long fins (XT Diving, C4, Leaderfins, etc.) fall in the 80–90 cm length range, so that’s the baseline for comparing these values.

The nuance: fins that bend closer to the footpocket always feel softer—even if the tip load matches a “harder” blade. When the flex starts near your feet the blade unloads early, the water sheds faster, and the kick feels lighter. If the bend moves toward the tip, it holds shape longer and feels stiffer.

docs.title: Hardness vs. Profile Table
docs.text:
Kg Tip Load Type 1 Type 2 Type 3 Type 4 Type 5 0.7 X X X X SSS 0.8 X X SSS SSS SS 0.9 X SSS SS SS S 1.0 SSS SS S - SS S MS 1.1 SS S S MS M 1.2 S S - MS MS M M - MH 1.3 MS MS - M MS - M MH H 1.4 M M M H HH 1.5 M MH MH HH HHH 1.6 MH H H HHH X 1.7 H HH HH X X 1.8 H HH X X X

Legend: SSS = very soft, SS = soft, S = slightly soft, MS = medium soft, M = medium, MH = medium hard, H = hard, HH/HHH = very hard, X = not recommended.

docs.title: Technique Notes
docs.text:
Profiles 1, 2, and 3 reward short, hip-driven kicks with a small amplitude. Overkicking just pushes them beyond the 90° sweet spot and you lose efficiency. Profiles 4 and 5 hang onto stiffness longer, so they tolerate larger kicks before collapsing.

For training, I’m leaning toward the softer profiles paired with a 0.9–1.1 kg tip load. They feel forgiving, still snap back cleanly, and keep the effort focused on clean technique instead of raw leg power.

docs.title: Research Notes: Playing With Cantilever Beam Calculator for Fin Blades
docs.text: I wanted to see how a simple cantilever beam model matches what happens with freediving fins. The idea is that a fin blade is essentially a thin rectangular beam clamped at the footpocket and loaded at the tip by the force of the water.

docs.title: Young’s modulus
docs.text:
• Prepreg sheet (Easy Composites high-strength carbon fibre sheet): ~32.4 GPa
  • Wet layup + vacuum bagging: 20–40 GPa, depending on resin content and fibre fraction
    • More resin → lower \(E\)
    • Better fibre alignment and compaction → higher \(E\)

docs.title: Moment of inertia \(I\)
docs.text:
For a rectangular section:

\[ I = \frac{b h^{3}}{12} \]
  • Blade width: \(b = 180\,\text{mm}\)
  • Thickness (3 layers @ 0.31 mm each): \(h = 0.93\,\text{mm}\)
\[ I \approx 12.1\,\text{mm}^4 \]

⚠️ This assumes uniform thickness along the length. Real fins are tapered, so actual \(I(x)\) varies with position.

docs.title: Cantilever beam calculator inputs
docs.text:
Using the online cantilever calculator:

  • Structure
    • Length \(L = 250\,\text{mm}\)
    • Elastic modulus \(E = 32\,\text{GPa} = 32{,}000\,\text{N/mm}^2\)
    • Moment of inertia \(I = 12\,\text{mm}^4\)
  • Imposed loading
    • Point load at tip
    • \(P = 2\,\text{kg}\)

docs.title: Results
docs.text: • Tip slope: ~–91°

docs.title: Takeaway
docs.text:
With only 2 kg load at the tip, the test piece bends almost to a right angle. This matches freediving practice: once a fin bends to ~90°, extra load doesn’t increase thrust, because the blade is already “giving way” to the water.

This simple cantilever model helps build some intuition into how many layers are needed to achieve a desired stiffness.

docs.title: Research Notes: Blade Lengths for Freediving
docs.text:
I finally pulled together a quick comparison of what "long" and "short" blades actually mean for bifins. Across the usual depth fin brands there is a pretty clear split between competition-length blades and travel/pool blades.

The tables below track total blade length, the "free" blade that extends past the footpocket, and any extra notes on where the numbers come from. It's not exhaustive, but it gives a feel for the ranges.

docs.title: Long blades
docs.text: Model Total length (mm) Free blade (mm) Width (mm) Link Notes Cetma Taras Carbon ~800 (650 + 150 footpocket) 650 190 Link Used by Mateusz Malina & William Joy. XT Pro (Pteryx Long Wide) 870 ~720 190 Link — Molchanovs Sport Bifin 3 Carbon 760 600 190 Link Used by Alexey Molchanov.

docs.title: Short blades
docs.text: Model Total length (mm) Free blade (mm) Width (mm) Link Notes Prussian Blue Travel (PB50) 550 400 220 Link — Molchanovs Sport Short Carbon 570 420 200 Link —

docs.title: Quick takeaways
docs.text:
• Long fins run about 760–870 mm total with a 600–720 mm free blade. These are the depth workhorses.
  • Short fins are around 550–570 mm total with a 400–420 mm free blade. Easy to travel with and great for pool drills.

I'm leaning toward keeping both pairs in rotation: long blades for serious depth days, short blades for technique and pool work without hauling a massive fin bag around.

docs.title: Materials Directory
docs.text:
A single place to keep track of every consumable, component, or tool that feeds into ApneaScrap Lab builds. Each page now stores the purchase history we have personally recorded so that techniques can reference a neutral material while still pointing back to real prices.

Only the regions where we hold purchase data are listed. At the moment that means the United Kingdom. When new data comes in for other locales we can extend each page with additional purchase rows.

docs.title: How to contribute
docs.text:
1. Create or update the material page with:
  2. a short overview and any usage notes;
  3. the material front matter block shown below, including at least one purchase entry for every supplier-region pair;
  4. a No purchase history recorded yet. call so the macro can turn the recorded purchases into tables grouped by region.
  5. Link techniques and projects to the material page instead of hard-coding suppliers inside a build guide.
  6. When logging a new technique version, add a bill_of_materials list in the front matter and render it with No bill of materials recorded yet.. Reference materials via their page path and set quantity.unit so the macro can match the recorded purchase data automatically. Skip purchase hints on technique entries—the macro infers the correct record from the unit you supply. Quantities default to the chosen purchase unit, so you only need to describe the amount being used.

Need a new material? Duplicate the template below.

---
title: Example Material
material:
  purchases:
    - supplier: "Supplier name"
      url: "https://example.com/product"
      region: UK
      date: 2025-06
      unit: example-unit
      price:
        amount: 12.34
        currency: GBP
      notes: "What makes this purchase representative"
---

docs.title: Choosing Bi-fin Foot Pockets - V1 - Short Rails
docs.text: Active

docs.title: Goal
docs.text: Choose the right freediving foot pockets for DIY carbon blades, focusing on performance-critical features.

docs.title: Specifications / Dimensions
docs.text:
• Foot pocket rails: short to allow the carbon blade to flex freely
  • Blade angle: 20°–33° for better body position and surface gliding
  • Attachment system: two-point (blade pocket + screws) for secure hold

docs.title: Reference Images
docs.text: Example Foot pocket

docs.title: Bill of Materials
docs.text: Material Quantity Unit Cost Line Cost Bifin Foot PocketsPair of angled freediving pockets with short rails 1 pair £36.00 - £58.00 per pair (recorded range)

docs.title: Instructions (step-by-step)
docs.text:
1. Check rail length

    • Choose pockets with short or low-profile rails so the blade can bend and return energy efficiently (see rubber fin rails for sourcing options).
    • Avoid long or stiff rails that dampen flex, especially on short training blades.
    • Review current supplier pricing on the bifin foot pockets material page — budget listings can differ from retail stock.

  2. Check blade angle

    • Select pockets with 20°–33° blade angle.
    • Larger angles favor surface swimming and gliding.
    • Smaller angles or flat pockets may feel more responsive but are less efficient for pool or surface work.

  3. Check attachment system

    • Ensure the pockets use a two-point attachment:
      • Blade slides into the pocket slot
      • Screws lock it in place
    • This system is standard for modern freediving pockets and ensures a secure, repeatable fit.

docs.title: Creating Laminating Base - V2 - Plastic Wedges
docs.text:
Research

This document describes how to build a modular acrylic base with wedge supports for laminating carbon fins. The example shown is for a 70 × 70 cm monofin, but the same technique can be adapted for bifins or other blade sizes.

docs.title: Goal
docs.text: Provide a modular surface with adjustable wedges to support blades during lamination.

docs.title: Specifications / Dimensions
docs.text:
• Target working area (monofin example): ~80 × 90 cm
  • Purpose: Provides enough surface for a 70 × 70 cm monofin blade plus sealing margin
  • Support requirement: Must be placed on a flat, rigid surface such as a table or workbench
  • Protection: Place a plastic sheet under the base to protect the table surface

docs.title: Bill of Materials
docs.text: Material Quantity Unit Cost Line Cost Acrylic sheet (A3, 2 mm)Six panels for modular monofin base 1 6 pack A3 sheet (2 mm) £16.00 per 6 pack A3 sheet (2 mm) £16.00 Stackable plastic wedgesAdjustable supports for the angled foot pocket section 1 pack (18 wedges) £7.00 per Pack of 18 wedges £7.00 Protective plastic sheetDisposable sheet to protect the bench surface 1 sheet Inexpensive Electrical tape rollWide PVC tape to join acrylic seams 1 roll Inexpensive Total £23.00

docs.title: Tools Required
docs.text: Tool Purpose Isopropyl alcohol and cloth Clean acrylic edges before applying tape Scissors or knife Trim electrical tape to length Measuring tape or ruler Align wedges consistently across the base Squeegee, roller, or thumb pressure Press the tape firmly onto the acrylic for a flat seal

docs.title: Instructions (step-by-step)
docs.text:
1. Prepare the surface

    • Place a plastic sheet on a flat, rigid table or bench.
    • Ensure there is no dust or debris under the plastic.

  2. Arrange acrylic sheets

    • Flat blade section: 4 A3 sheets in a 2 × 2 layout (~59 × 84 cm).
    • Footpocket section: 2 A3 sheets side by side (~29.7 × 84 cm).

  3. Join sheets

    • Clean edges with isopropyl alcohol.
    • Bridge each joint with electrical tape, overlapping slightly (1–2 mm).
    • Press tape firmly to remove trapped air and keep surface flush.

  4. Add wedge supports

    • Place plastic stackable wedges under the footpocket section.
    • Adjust wedge height to set the required angle (typically 20–30° for a monofin).
    • Ensure wedges are stable and evenly distributed.

docs.title: Data to Record / Results
docs.text:
• Wedge heights and resulting angles
  • Notes on surface gaps or leaks during lamination

docs.title: Benefits
docs.text:
• This version does not require a heavy wooden support structure, making it much easier and faster to put together.
  • Modular design — acrylic sheets and wedges can be stored flat and reused for different versions.

docs.title: Limitations
docs.text:
• The base cannot be placed as a whole into a vacuum bag.
  • The only viable vacuum method is sealing the edges of the bag around the acrylic surface, which is less flexible than a solid one-piece base.

docs.title: Cutting Cured Carbon - V1 - Junior Hacksaw
docs.text: Active

docs.title: Goal
docs.text: To cut cured carbon laminate into the desired shape using a simple junior hacksaw method, ensuring a clean fit into the final assembly.

docs.title: Bill of Materials
docs.text: No bill of materials recorded yet.

docs.title: Tools Required
docs.text: Tool Purpose Junior hacksaw with a fine-tooth metal blade Cut the cured carbon cleanly without fraying Metal file Deburr and smooth the cut edges Safety goggles, dust mask, and protective gloves Shield eyes, lungs, and skin from carbon dust and splinters

docs.title: Instructions (step-by-step)
docs.text:
1. Safety: Wear gloves, eye protection, and a dust mask. Perform all steps in a well-ventilated area.
  2. Attach the cutting template to the cured laminate using electrical tape.
  3. Hold the laminate securely on a stable surface.
  4. Use a junior hacksaw with a fine-tooth metal blade to slowly cut along the template line. Apply steady pressure and avoid forcing the saw.
  5. Once the piece is cut, smooth the edges with a metal file.
  6. Test the fit by inserting the blade into the foot pocket.
  7. If it does not fit properly, continue filing the edges gradually until the correct fit is achieved.

docs.title: Limitations
docs.text:
• Sawing generates dust and small splinters — PPE is required
  • Cutting is slow and requires quite some effort, depending on how thick the laminate is

docs.title: Finishing Carbon - V1 - Epoxy and Clear Coat
docs.text: Active

docs.title: Goal
docs.text: To apply a protective and aesthetic finish to cured carbon blades by sealing, smoothing, and clear-coating the surface. This improves durability, protects against moisture, enhances gloss, and provides the option for custom decals.

docs.title: Bill of Materials
docs.text: Material Quantity Unit Cost Line Cost Laminating Epoxy SystemThin finishing coat (approx. 100 ml mixed) 0.2 500 ml kit £15.00 per 500 ml kit £3.00 Clear Coat SprayThree light lacquer passes for UV protection 0.3 400 ml can £8.00 per 400 ml can £2.40 Sandpaper set400, 600, and 1000 grit sheets 1 set £3.00 £3.00 Printable vinyl decal sheet (optional)Gloss white adhesive sheet for logosOptional branding layer 1 sheet £1.50 £1.50 Total £9.90

docs.title: Tools Required
docs.text: Tool Purpose Mixing cups Measure and combine resin with hardener Small brush Spread the epoxy and clear coat evenly Sandpaper (400 / 600 grit; 1000 grit optional) Level and smooth the cured surface between coats Gloves Keep resin and solvents off your hands Eye protection Guard against splashes while applying resin Well-ventilated workspace Provide airflow to control fumes and cure safely

docs.title: Instructions (step-by-step)
docs.text:
1. Safety

    • Wear gloves and eye protection.
    • Work in a well-ventilated area.

  2. Resin Finishing Layer

    • Mix resin and hardener as usual.
    • Apply a thin finishing coat with a brush over the cured carbon surface.
    • Smooth out imperfections.
    • Allow resin to fully cure.
    • Clean the brush immediately after use.

  3. Optional Sanding

    • If a smoother or glossier surface is desired, sand the cured resin lightly.
    • Start with 400 grit, then move to 600 grit.
    • Finish with 1000 grit if you want a mirror-like polish.
    • Skip this step if surface smoothness is not critical.

  4. Optional Decal Application

    • Print the logo onto the back of vinyl sticker paper. Download the printable logo

    • Cut out the design.

    • Apply the decal carefully onto the carbon surface.

  5. Clear Coat

    • Spray the entire surface with acrylic clear coat.
    • Apply 3 light, even layers.
    • Allow proper drying time between layers.

docs.title: Limitations
docs.text:
• Requires time and patience for curing and sanding.
  • Gloss finish depends on sanding quality and spray application.

docs.title: Gluing Fin Rails - V1 - Two Part Plastic-to-Carbon Adhesive
docs.text: Active

docs.title: Goal
docs.text: To attach rubber fin rails securely to carbon fiber blades using a strong composite adhesive. The rails protect the blade edges, improve water flow, and extend the blade’s lifespan.

docs.title: Bill of Materials
docs.text: Material Quantity Unit Cost Line Cost Rubber Fin RailsOne pair of soft rubber rails sized for bifin blades 2 m (enough for four rails) £6.00 per metre £12.00 Plastic to Carbon Adhesive25 ml of 3M DP420 mixed with nozzle 1 25 ml syringe £8.25 per 25 ml syringe £8.25 Fold-back clips set20 mm binder clips for clamping rails during cure 1 set Inexpensive Total £20.25

docs.title: Tools Required
docs.text: Tool Purpose Gloves Keep the two-part adhesive off your skin Sandpaper (around 400 grit) Key both surfaces to improve adhesion Window cleaner Degrease the blade and rails before bonding

docs.title: Instructions (step-by-step)
docs.text:
1. Safety

    • Wear gloves to avoid skin contact with adhesive.
    • Work in a ventilated space.

  2. Surface Preparation

    • Sand the edge of the carbon blade lightly with 400-grit sandpaper.
    • Sand the inside surface of the rubber fin rail to improve adhesion.
    • Clean both the blade edge and the inside of the rail with window cleaner.

  3. Apply Adhesive

    • Mix the two-part adhesive according to the manufacturer’s instructions.
    • Apply the adhesive generously inside the fin rail.
    • Press the rail firmly onto the blade edge, ensuring full contact along the surface.
    • Check carefully for gaps — even small gaps can expand over time and risk detachment.

  4. Remove Excess Adhesive

    • Wipe off any excess adhesive that squeezes out during pressing.

  5. Clamp the Rails

    • Secure the rails in place using fold-back paper clips spaced evenly along the edge.

  6. Curing

    • Allow the adhesive to cure fully according to the manufacturer’s specifications (usually around 12 hours).

docs.title: Limitations
docs.text:
• Poor surface preparation (e.g., not sanding both blade edge and rail interior) may result in weak bonding.
  • Adhesive application must be uniform; gaps reduce durability and may lead to rail detachment over time.

docs.title: Bill of Materials
docs.text: Material Quantity Unit Cost Line Cost Carbon Fiber Fabric0.3 m² of 200 g/m² 3K 2/2 twill cloth 0.3 m² (1 m wide) £17.00 per m² (1 m wide) £5.10 Laminating Epoxy System200 g mixed resin (approx. 200 ml) 0.4 500 ml kit £15.00 per 500 ml kit £6.00 PVA Release AgentTwo thin coats on the laminating base 35 ml (two thin coats) £5.00 per 200 ml bottle £0.88 Peel PlyTwo layers cut to the blade outline 0.6 m (1.5 m wide) £12.00 per 5 m pack (1.5 m wide) £1.44 Consumables packGloves, mixing sticks, acetone wipes 1 pack £3.50 £3.50 Total £16.92

docs.title: Tools Required
docs.text: Tool Purpose Nitrile gloves Protect your hands while handling resin Mixing pots and sticks Measure and blend epoxy batches Laminating brushes Wet out the carbon fabric evenly Plastic finned roller (75 mm) Consolidate layers and push out trapped air Scissors for cutting fabric Cut reinforcement to the required templates Digital scale Weigh resin batches for accurate mix ratios Optional vacuum bagging kit Apply consolidation pressure when available

docs.title: Reference Images
docs.text: Wet Carbon Laminate Cured Carbon Laminate

docs.title: Instructions (step-by-step)
docs.text:
0. Safety first

  • Wear nitrile gloves and work in a well-ventilated area to avoid exposure to harmful fumes.

1. Prepare the work surface

  1. Pour a small amount of the PVA mold release agent into a cup.
  2. Using a brush, apply the release agent thinly and evenly over the working surface or mold.
  3. Tip: see this video at 2:00 for guidance.

2. Cut the carbon fiber cloth

  • Measure and cut the carbon fiber cloth to the desired dimensions.
  • Ensure smooth cuts to maintain structural strength along the fiber weave.

3. Prepare the epoxy resin

  1. Pour epoxy resin into a mixing pot.
  2. Use a ratio of 100:30 by weight (resin:hardener).
  3. Example: for 100 g of resin, add 30 g of hardener.
  4. Use the digital scale for precise measurement.
  5. Mix the resin and hardener thoroughly, but gently, to avoid introducing air bubbles.

4. Lay the resin and carbon cloth

  1. Spread an even layer of resin directly onto the prepared mold or surface.
  2. Lay the carbon fiber cloth over the resin layer.
  3. Apply another layer of resin over the cloth using the brush and smooth it out with the roller.
  4. Tip: use the roller to eliminate trapped air and ensure the cloth adheres evenly.

5. Apply peel ply

  1. Once the laminate layers are complete, apply two layers of peel ply over the top surface.
  2. Peel ply absorbs excess resin and helps achieve a uniform finish.
  3. Optional: include a breather layer to improve vacuum results.
  4. Optional: if using the vacuum bagging kit, place the prepared laminate inside one of the storage bags, seal it, and apply vacuum pressure with the manual pump.

6. Clean-up

  1. Clean all reusable tools (e.g., brushes) with acetone immediately after use.
  2. Discard used gloves, cups, and mixing sticks responsibly.

docs.title: Limitations
docs.text:
• Manual layup can trap more resin compared to vacuum processes.
  • Work time is limited once resin is mixed; prepare all materials in advance.

docs.title: Measuring Vacuum - V1 - Syringe Gauge
docs.text:
Research

A simple gauge to monitor mild vacuum (~81 kPa absolute, −20 kPa gauge) directly inside a vacuum bag. It uses Boyle’s law: trapped air expands as pressure drops, moving a rubber plunger seal you can read through the bag.

docs.title: Goal
docs.text: Monitor vacuum level inside a bag using plunger movement.

docs.title: Bill of Materials
docs.text: Material Quantity Unit Cost Line Cost 10 mL syringeThin barrel syringe for plunger travel 1 Inexpensive Luer-lock tip capSingle cap to seal the syringe tip 1 Inexpensive Candle wax shavingsSmall amount to lubricate the rubber seal 0.05 block Inexpensive

docs.title: Tools Required
docs.text: Tool Purpose Knife or scissors Trim tubing and syringe components to length Permanent marker Mark graduations and reference points on the gauge

docs.title: Instructions (step-by-step)
docs.text:
1. Modify plunger

    • Remove plunger from syringe.
    • Cut off the plastic rod, leaving only the rubber seal.

  2. Prepare barrel

    • Clean inside of syringe.
    • Lightly rub candle wax on the rubber seal for low friction.

  3. Seal the syringe

    • Insert rubber seal back into barrel at the start volume:
      • 5 mL mark for a 10 mL syringe
      • 10 mL mark for a 20 mL syringe
    • Cap the tip airtight with a Luer-lock or push-on tip cap.

  4. Mark the scale

    • Draw an ambient mark at the initial plunger position.
    • Mark your target 80% atmospheric (~81 kPa abs):
      • 10 mL syringe → +1.25 mL (plunger moves ~7.6 mm on standard barrel, ~20 mm on thin insulin barrel)
      • 20 mL syringe → +2.5 mL (plunger moves ~8.9 mm)

docs.title: Data to Record / Results
docs.text: Record plunger position at ambient and at target pressure.

docs.title: Predicting Flex Versions

Use simplified beam theory to estimate how new blade geometries will bend under load.

docs.title: Predicting Flex - V1 - Tapered Cantilever Beam
docs.text: Research

docs.title: Goal
docs.text:
Estimate deflection and curvature profiles for a planned blade using simple inputs such as length, taper, and modulus, allowing iterative layup adjustments without material usage.

The process involves dividing the blade into many small slices, calculating the bending contribution of each slice based on layer thickness, and summing these contributions to determine the overall deflection. The applied load is adjusted until the tip reaches the desired angle, after which SVG visualizations and inertia values are generated.

The calculations follow Euler–Bernoulli beam theory principles. You can explore cantilever beam calculations here.

docs.title: Limitations
docs.text:
• Simplifies the fin as a tapered Euler–Bernoulli beam, which may not capture all real-world complexities.
  • Approximates the values for E (modulus) and I (moment of inertia), making precise computation challenging.

docs.title: Vacuum Bagging Carbon - V1 - Enclosed Bagging
docs.text: Active

docs.title: Goal
docs.text: To create a simple, low-cost vacuum environment for small parts using the manual pump and storage bags from the vacuum bagging kit.

docs.title: Specifications / Dimensions
docs.text:
• Suitable for small to medium parts that fit inside standard vacuum storage bags
  • Maximum part size: limited to the largest bag available
  • Pressure achievable: approximately -0.2 to -0.4 bar with a manual pump
  • Requires a flat, rigid base (e.g. acrylic sheet) to support the part

docs.title: Bill of Materials
docs.text: Material Quantity Unit Cost Line Cost Vacuum Bagging KitHeavy-duty storage bag plus compatible hand pump 1 kit £9.00 per kit £9.00 Breather ClothWraps part to distribute airflow 0.5 m (1 m wide) £12.00 per 5 m pack (1 m wide) £1.20 Total £10.20

docs.title: Tools Required
docs.text: Tool Purpose Metal file Smooth base edges so they do not puncture the bag Scissors Cut breather cloth and consumables to size

docs.title: Instructions (step-by-step)
docs.text:
1. Smooth the edges of the base or part using the file to prevent puncturing the vacuum bag.
  2. Place breather cloth around the part to allow airflow inside the bag.
  3. Add an extra layer of breather cloth directly under the vacuum pump connector since this point receives the highest pressure.
  4. Place the entire setup into the vacuum bag.
  5. Seal the bag securely according to the supplier’s instructions.
  6. Use the manual pump to create a vacuum. Stop when the base begins to bend slightly, ensuring enough pressure without risking deformation.
  7. Check the bag after 10 minutes. If the vacuum is lost, the bag may be perforated. Replace the bag and restart the process.

docs.title: Limitations
docs.text:
• Requires a solid base that can be lifted and inserted into the bag
  • Enclosed vacuum bagging limits the maximum part size to the bag dimensions
  • If the angled part of the acrylic base bends too much under vacuum, the resulting blade might not fit into the foot pocket

docs.title: Vacuum Bagging Carbon - V2 - Edge-Sealed Bagging
docs.text: Research

docs.title: Goal
docs.text: To enable vacuum bagging of larger parts by sealing a cut vacuum bag directly to the laminating base using butyl tape, while achieving a controlled and measurable vacuum level.

docs.title: Specifications / Dimensions
docs.text:
• Suitable for medium to large parts (size limited only by base and bag film availability)
  • Target vacuum level: ~80% vacuum (-0.2 bar relative to atmosphere)
  • Requires a rigid, smooth laminating base for edge sealing

docs.title: Bill of Materials
docs.text: Material Quantity Unit Cost Line Cost Vacuum Bagging KitManual pump with heavy-duty storage bags for low-cost vacuum pulls 1 kit £9.00 per kit £9.00 Butyl Sealing TapeContinuous bead around the laminating base 0.4 15 m roll (12 mm) £6.50 per 15 m roll (12 mm) £2.60 Breather ClothUnder-bag airflow path and resin catch 0.6 m (1 m wide) £12.00 per 5 m pack (1 m wide) £1.44 DIY Vacuum gaugeInline gauge to monitor vacuum level 1 gauge Inexpensive Total £13.04

docs.title: Tools Required
docs.text: Tool Purpose Metal roller or rounded tool Press the butyl sealing tape firmly to the base Scissors or utility knife Cut the bag film and breather cloth to size Cleaning cloth and window cleaner Remove dust and grease before sealing the bag edges

docs.title: Instructions (step-by-step)
docs.text:
1. Clean the laminating base edges thoroughly using a cloth and window cleaner to ensure the butyl tape adheres properly.
  2. Cut a sheet of vacuum bag film with sufficient margin to cover the part completely on all sides.
  3. Apply a continuous strip of butyl sealing tape along the edges of the laminating base.
  4. Lay the vacuum bag film over the base, pressing it firmly into the butyl tape to create an airtight seal.
  5. Ensure the vacuum valve is positioned away from critical laminate parts such as the free blade.
  6. Arrange breather cloth around the part to support airflow under the bag, and place an extra layer beneath the valve.
  7. Pump manually while monitoring the gauge, stopping once ~80% vacuum (-0.2 bar) is achieved.
  8. Check for leaks by verifying the gauge holds steady for at least 10 minutes. If vacuum drops, inspect and reseal the edges as needed.

docs.title: Limitations
docs.text:
• Requires a clean and smooth base surface for proper sealing; dust, grease, or moisture will cause leaks
  • More setup time compared to enclosed bagging
